title: Part 1
content:
Part 1

SEVERAL MORE MINUTES passed. While discussing the various ways to handle their weapons, the guards experimented with different stances and grips.

Meanwhile, I looked through the details in the rulebook, at the rules that would incur a major penalty.

Major Penalties (For each infraction, a deduction of 100 Class Points and in serious cases, expulsion.)

-Acts such as assault, restraint, or destroying or stealing guns.

-A student who has been judged 'out' intentionally continuing to fight back.

-Acts such as stealing or taking items from other classes.

-False reports in response to school inquiries.

-Other behavior that undermines the dignity of the special exam.

Mashima-sensei also verbally explained about attacking after being judged 'out', but unless it was intentional—including attacks on opponents outside of exam hours—it wasn't subject to a penalty. However, even if someone feigned an unintentional attack, the target wouldn't be declared 'out' and would be given relief, so there was little point in pushing the boundaries. Of course, it wasn't impossible to find loopholes if one looked for them, but it wasn't worth the risk of breaking the rules.

This was because the school had a strong will to thoroughly enforce the rules. It was precisely because this was an uninhabited island exam where gray areas could emerge that I understood the phrase 'behavior that undermines the dignity of the special exam' was a warning that they would show absolutely no mercy.

Since actions that were close to a gray area came with high risks, it was safe to assume that even Ryuuen wouldn't be able to execute them.

"Ayanokouji, we got a new report from Shimazaki. He says Class A's advanced to the point where they'll be entering area G8 soon."

Hashimoto was the first to react to the new report from the commander.

"Got it, the situation with Horikita's class. What's next?"

"Hold on. Before that—it seems Koenji's GPS has already entered I9."

"I9? Damn, he's fast."

There was no one other than Koenji who could move as swiftly on a mountain path as on a flat road.

"What about Ryuuen's class?"

"Hold on a sec. Shimazaki, what's the status of Class B?"

He pressed for an answer from the commander, but with the VIP acting as an intermediary, the process was time-inefficient.

"Not being able to talk to the commander directly... this might be more of a pain than I thought."

Growing impatient from the unavoidable, forced wait, Hashimoto let out a sigh.

"The exam's only just begun. There's no need to rush."

Morishita, who sat down on the ground to take a complete break, muttered without looking at Hashimoto.

"This special exam is on a deserted island, so the rewards are pretty huge, y'know. Plus, if we get hit with the total annihilation penalty, someone's gonna get expelled. It'd be unreasonable not to get fired up."

"Ayanokouji Kiyotaka said as much, but when push comes to shove, Hashimoto Masayoshi is our only choice."

"Hey, don't just go deciding that on your own. You should be the one to say something to her spouting off whatever she wants."

"..."

"Ah, Ayanokouji? You're not... If we lose, you're not actually gonna make me the sacrificial lamb for expulsion, are—"

"Relax. I won't do that."

"You sure about that? What was with that pause just now? Huh?"

"I was just responding to the setup."

"...You better be telling the truth."

"You seem to have gotten more of a scare than I expected."

Hashimoto forced a wry smile, looking annoyed at Morishita for her constant retorts.

"It seems Class B has stopped moving for now, just like us."

That report came from Takemoto's mouth, and Hashimoto nodded once.

"They're probably just relieved to have gotten some distance from Ayanokouji. They're likely doing the same as us—using the time to talk things over. Whether or not you've been coached on how to use the weapons makes a huge difference in accuracy, after all. Heh, I'll bet they were on pins and needles, worried we'd come to the west side."

It seemed Ichinose's class had also stopped and perhaps shifted to discussions as well. I had Takemoto reply that no reports on Class D were necessary for the time being unless there were major developments.

A little while later, a radio call came in from the commander, this time for Shiraishi.

"He says, 'I'm reporting because we've learned a few things about Ayanokouji-kun's request.'"

After she relayed that, Shiraishi once again listened to the voice coming from her earphone.

"Apparently, the commanders were informed that during the special exam, direct contact, private conversations and any message-like exchanges are prohibited. And the tablet's screenshot function is disabled; even if you try to use it, it will only save a completely black screen as the picture—that's what he said."

"I thought I saw him talking to Shimazaki when we split up, but he even asked him to check on all that?"

"I had him look into it because I thought there might be things he could do outside of his official authority as commander, but it seems they're being monitored more strictly than I anticipated. They may be sharing the space called the main base, but the premise is likely that the commanders are all in separate locations."

"Also, it seems the GPS on the tablet's map has individual tags, and he found out it's possible to take notes on the GPS of students from other classes. So, he said he made sure to put Koenji-kun's name on the GPS marker at I9, where he's isolated."

"Got it. Tell Shimazaki I said thanks, and to let us know anytime if anything else comes up."

I broke my gaze from Shiraishi, who nodded and I took off my goggles for a moment. I looked at the classmates I'd lined up in a column and with an assault rifle in one hand, I moved to a place where everyone could see me.

"Once the event begins, our movements will become hectic. Furthermore, depending on the quality of our supplies, the possibility of combat will gradually increase. That's why I'm going to take the time now to properly lecture you all on how to use these weapons. Then, after the lecture, I want one of the guards who isn't confident in their fighting ability to temporarily give their weapon to one of the three VIPs, one after another. And every few hours, collect it and have a different guard hand over their weapon. I want them to constantly be in rotation with someone."

"What do you mean by that? The VIPs are forbidden from using weapons, right? No... is that exactly why...?"

He had a moment of doubt, but Toba immediately understood what it meant.

"Yeah. One method for identifying another class's VIP is to see if they can use a weapon. If we get into an unexpected fight, it's entirely conceivable that they'll prioritize targeting any student without one."

Of course, during an engagement, one guard would be unable to function, but I wanted to include the element of misdirection as a form of insurance.

"So this will stop the enemy from easily identifying our VIPs?"

"That's right. However, just in case, when you hand a weapon to a VIP, I want you to be sure to remove the magazine and check the chamber as well. I want to reduce the risk of them firing reflexively when attacked by another class to zero."

"Huh? What was that? Chamber?"

"The firing chamber—basically, there might be cases where a round remains inside even after you remove the magazine. I plan on carefully checking the structure of these paint guns later to see how they actually work, but if we build this routine from the start, we can prevent mistakes."

I took the assault rifle in my hands, showed them how to remove the magazine and demonstrated how to check the chamber. Then, I handed it to Toba and taught him the method via a hands-on demonstration.

"...You're awfully knowledgeable about this stuff. You look like you belong holding a weapon, too."

He muttered that after checking it himself a few times to learn the movements.

"Regarding this type of firearm, Ijuuin from Horikita's class is very knowledgeable and he taught me a few things in the past. It seems that knowledge, which I initially thought was useless, has proven to be useful."

"Is that so... In that case, they'll probably adopt a similar strategy, of course."

It was true that Ijuuin was knowledgeable about guns, but he never taught me anything in the past.

I'd never held this type of gun outside of the toy ones from the culture festival, but I knew about them because I had experience learning about firearms through my knowledge from the White Room.

That being said, Toba had no way to confirm whether this story was true, so it likely wouldn't be a problem.

"Anyway, I understand the aim. I should also practice when I have some free time, right?"

I recalled that Toba, who was athletic, was also good at basketball. Since he also achieved good results in P.E. classes, he would likely be a more capable fighter than the other students. Perhaps it was because he felt he had to be the one to lead that he was so proactively stepping forward.

From there, I settled down in that spot, taught them how to handle the weapons and showed them things like how powerful the shots were by actually firing a few rounds at a tree.

I really wanted to let everyone have a test shot, but I wanted to avoid wasting ammunition in the current situation.

Radio reports came in periodically and after another ten minutes, Horikita's class was still pushing north without changing course, while the remaining two classes appeared to have stopped to discuss and were continuing to formulate their strategies.

Just as I was getting the hang of the weapons, Kitou approached me with an assault rifle in hand.

"...Let me confirm something, just to be sure. You're aiming to take first place in this exam... Am I right to think that?"

"That's surprising, Kitou. I didn't expect you to ask something like that."

"A survival game... This feels like nothing more than playtime, but if we're aiming to win, I'm going to take this seriously."

"Ayanokouji is betting his own expulsion on this, you know? Of course he's going to play for real."

As if worried that infighting amongst us would cause trouble, Hashimoto immediately cut in here as well.

"It's certain that aiming to lose isn't an option."

He came to get a verbal commitment to win from me, who was staking my own expulsion on this challenge.

Was it perhaps because he couldn't sense any fighting spirit from me? Or was it simply that Kitou's intuition was at work?

"But you've touched on a good point."

Either way, it seemed I had to revise my evaluation of Kitou just a little.

"Unfortunately, even if you want first place, it seems I won't be able to live up to that expectation."

When I answered him so honestly, Kitou faintly furrowed his brow and narrowed his eyes.

"...In other words, you're not confident?"

Kitou's eyes, which already held a sharp glint, grew even more intense and stern.

"I don't think it'll be an easy win, but that's not it."

I paused, looked away from Kitou in front of me for a moment and glanced around at my surroundings.

Of course, not a single student was missing.

"This is a good opportunity. It might seem like I'm derailing things a bit, but please listen."

I addressed all of my classmates, who were watching to see what I would say.

"I believe this class's ultimate goal, the rank we should be aiming for, is second place."

In an instant, everyone there fell silent.

"Second place? I mean, I wouldn't say it's a bad goal, but what's the deal with aiming for that right from the start?"

Everyone first aimed for first place. That was the natural mindset one should have.

That was precisely why Shimizu was surprised and tilted his head. He didn't even try to hide his dissatisfaction with the passive answer.

"The reason is simple and clear. I'm thinking we can give first place to Ichinose's class."

"...Huh? What the hell is that? I have no clue what you mean."

With the exception of a very small number of people like Hashimoto and Morishita, it was natural that they wouldn't be able to understand what I was saying.

The alliance between Class C and Class D that I'd arranged between Ichinose and myself.

The special exam was the most suitable time to bring up that topic and it was a situation where it was essential to announce it at this point.

"It's not easy to rebuild this class, which has fallen to Class C over the past year and raise it to Class A. I think you all can understand that, given your past where you'd all but given up."

Even after hearing the hard-to-accept statement that I intended to give up first place, my classmates were surprised and confused, but they didn't get terribly upset.

They seemed willing to listen first before raising any objections.

"I transferred to raise this class to Class A. But given that the hurdle is actually very high, we must use a strategy to win efficiently. And one of those important strategies is Ichinose's class—"

At that moment, Hashimoto showed a dubious look for an instant.

Or rather, it should be said that he couldn't suppress his impulse.

"Hey, Ayanokouji..."

He hurriedly came between the students and forcefully interrupted me.

Then he leaned in close and whispered in my ear.

"You should probably stop talking about that here. No matter how you look at it, now's not the time..."

We were just about to all pull together to win this special exam.

It was the most unsuitable topic to bring up at such a time.

"What is this 'one important strategy'?"

"Oh, that's— uhm—"

Even Hashimoto couldn't seem to come up with a good excuse on the spot and his agitation was clearly showing.

However, I ignored Hashimoto's advice and words and continued.

"That strategy, I believe, lies in an alliance with Ichinose's class."

I said it.

Hashimoto's expression was striking to see up close, but the looks on my classmates' faces were even more intense.

"Wait... what? An alliance...? What are you—"

In front of the bewildered students, I began to explain the advantages of the alliance.

I explained that we should form a cooperative relationship, something that couldn't be established with Class A or Class B, who we should be chasing. It was a partnership that could only be realized because we were both lower-ranked classes and because we were dealing with the trustworthy Ichinose's class.

I verbally conveyed the specific contract details of the alliance to my classmates.

When faced with an exam where all four classes competed, the win would be given to the class with even one fewer Class Point. Of course, it wasn't about giving away victory for free.

If we conceded the victory here, this class, which would then fall to Class D, would in turn gain the full cooperation of Ichinose's class.

"In this survival exam, we're supposed to be fighting three other classes. That means we're facing nearly 120 enemies, but an alliance can change that premise. I don't need to explain in detail how effective that would be."

"If Class D is on our side, we can focus just on Class A and Class B... huh."

"It's not just that. At the same time the number of enemies decreases, the number of allies increases by that same amount. That alone brings victory much closer."

Making the most of the alliance was vital.

"I think it's a good idea. It'd be no laughing matter if we gave it our all and ended up in last, or third place at best. But if we can take it a little easier and secure second, that's not a bad deal. We can steadily earn Class Points and close the gap with A and B. After this, there should be another academic exam, too."

With that, we would accelerate further and by then all four classes would be on even footing. Those were Hashimoto's words, describing a prospect that wasn't unrealistic, but many students were left with things they couldn't quite digest.

Morishita's gaze alone seemed to say, 'You really shouldn't be sticking your neck out.'

Morishita, who also knew about the alliance, probably felt the same way as Hashimoto.

"If you're bringing up an alliance now, that means things are already moving behind the scenes, right?"

How I answered here was extremely important.

That we already formed the alliance and that it was now unavoidable.

Answering like that would be easy, but it wasn't the optimal solution.

"You could say a provisional agreement has been made. The other side is keen on it."

"Well, of course they are. They've got no way of moving up otherwise."

It wasn't just that he was looking down on Class D, but an answer based on the flow of events so far.

Not only the harsh Matoba, but many of the people here thought so.

"You can refuse—or rather, reject the idea—but it's not something we can pick up and drop as we please. If you reject it, we'll never be able to team up with Class D again and depending on the situation, there's a slight risk that Class D could team up with Class A or Class B. That's something you'll have to be prepared for."

"That's a pretty selfish proposition."

It was a normal reaction to want to criticize the part about trying to form an alliance.

Matoba was dumbfounded, at a loss for words.

As if slipping through that brief moment of silence, Motodoi lightly raised her hand.

"Let me say something, too. This talk about an alliance... do we have to decide right now? No matter how you look at it, this isn't the right time. I'll admit, this special exam isn't exactly in our favor. But to throw away first place and aim for second just to get a better advantage... I can't accept that. It's less about not wanting to let Class D win and more that I don't want to throw away our own chance of winning."

"I agree. So basically, we're the ones who have to suck up and bring them a gift, right? 'We'll make you number one, so let's team up.' What's up with that? In case you forgot, we're the ones who are supposed to be on top here."

He avoided saying it directly, but he probably wanted to say that if anyone was going to be bringing a gift, it should be Class D.

I could sense that feeling from Matoba—no, from many of my classmates.

"Just when this pain-in-the-ass exam starts, you drop a bombshell like this on us. And the fact that Hashimoto's so into the idea is shady as hell."

Morishita's gaze changed to a triumphant one, as if to say, 'See?'

Hashimoto, who was normally the type to be suspicious if anything, had been in favor of the alliance from the very first word. It was only natural for them to be dissatisfied, thinking he must have been told about it beforehand.

Wondering if he overstepped this time, Hashimoto involuntarily looked up at the sky.

"How about we discipline them?"

"No need."

But I had no intention of blaming Hashimoto for his actions and words, nor did I find him annoying.

Rather, I considered it a necessary spice.

"Look, we're not going to form an alliance just from this one discussion. There's no way. That said, I'm not going to reject the idea out of hand, either. So we can have time to really think about whether this is necessary, can't we postpone this conversation until after the special exam is over?"

Considering that no objections erupted from the other students, it seemed any further effort would be a waste of time.

There was no need to struggle here any further.

Negative opinions and criticisms of the alliance were things that could be easily overturned with a single change in perspective. All I had to do was make them feel that what they thought they didn't need was, in fact, necessary.

This was a big step toward that goal.

"My bad for bringing this up so suddenly. Like Matoba and the others said, let's talk about the alliance again after this special exam is over. For now, just forget we had this conversation."

When I answered in a way that seemed to concede, Matoba, as if his rising anger had subsided, nodded emphatically.

Just then.

A faint wind blew.

The sound of rustling trees.

At the same time, I faintly picked up on multiple other sounds from a distance.

No one else sensed anything.

Of course.

Until just a moment ago, they had been completely at ease, hearing reports on the other classes' locations from Shimazaki every five minutes.

Deep down, no one wanted to engage in combat this early in the game.

That assumption had bred carelessness.

"Hashimoto."

"Hm?"

Sensing a change in my demeanor, Hashimoto tilted his head curiously.

My gaze was directed past Hashimoto, past the rear guard and deeper into the forest where visibility was poor.

"—Everyone, run! Now!"

"Huh? What do you mean by—"

Immediately after, our surroundings erupted as if they'd been brought to a sudden boil. It was as if the volume on a muted television had been cranked to MAX all at once.

"There they are! Fire, fire, fire!!"

"It's Class C! Get 'em!"

"Go, go, go, go, go!"

Numerous shouts came from within the forest. I couldn't identify whose voices they were, but I was certain of one thing: they didn't belong to the boys or girls of our Class C.

In an instant, they appeared from deep within the trees.

At the same time, no, even before that, a rain of paintballs flew into view.

No, it might be more accurate to call it a torrential downpour raging from the side.

It was a storm of paintballs, far from accurate, that relied on sheer numbers.

More than half of them were blocked by the large, natural trees that served as cover and missed their mark, but the remaining paintballs reached the Class C students.

A paintball hit and burst on the shoulder of Morishige, who was standing at the very back.

He had yet to process what just happened and wore a dumbfounded look.

Immediately after, a paintball struck Motodoi in the hip and she let out a small shriek from the impact.

From there, their thoughts instantly plunged into a state of panic.

Some realized they were enemies and tried to raise their guns, only to be covered in paint.

Others dropped their weapons to escape, or were hit with paintballs as they went back for the backpacks they'd forgotten at their feet.

In just a few short seconds, the casualties began to mount among the classmates at the rear. Then, the figures of the enemy came into view, revealing which class was behind the surprise attack.

But there was no time to talk about that now.

"Your packs, don't forget your packs! Just run!"

Hashimoto shouted to his classmates, waving his arm broadly to beckon them over.

"We don't even know how many of them there are. For now, run! Just run!"

Hashimoto repeatedly shouted, but his voice was mostly drowned out by panicked thoughts and screams.

"Kitou—"

I was about to give an order to Kitou in the back, but it seemed there was no need for a detailed verbal explanation.

The moment our eyes met, or perhaps even before they did, his brain—or maybe his body—had already understood the predicament and he broke into a run.

For all of Class C to turn their backs and flee would only increase our losses unnecessarily.

Therefore, having a few people stay here and hold off the enemy was one of the few options available.

Kitou immediately took cover behind a large nearby tree and began to counterattack.

He showed a glimpse of skill and courage that made it hard to believe he'd never fired a single shot in a real fight before.

He must have taken out one of his opponents, as an alarm from a wristwatch rang out from deep within the unseen trees.

The enemy, who'd been attacking on the momentum of their surprise attack alone, was halted for the first time and took cover behind a large tree.

Inspired by Kitou's swift counterattack, Machida and several other boys, though a bit late, also managed to take cover and began firing back blindly, with no time to take proper aim.

"We'll leave this place to Kitou and the others and retreat."

I called out only to the front line, which hadn't taken any casualties yet and hastily left the area.

Shiraishi and Hashimoto followed, moving frantically to catch up.

Angry shouts, screams and the sounds of paint guns firing flew through the air.

With those sounds at my back, I took the lead and forged a path forward.

It became clear as I actually passed through. While nature remained untouched, simple, narrow, man-made paths were made in places to make it easier for people to walk. This uninhabited island might be subject to some changes in the future. Nevertheless, we couldn't let our guard down for a moment. One step off that path and you were in the deep woods. If we didn't flee prepared to get a few scrapes, the damage would surely have been greater.

toc.label: Classroom of the Elite  Year 3, Volume 3
Chapter 1: Opening. Survival Game Special Exam.
Chapter 7: The Time of the Decisive Battle
Epilogue: Show Me What Youve Got
